title: sainsburys security cases honey jar shoplifting
story: Shoplifters have targeted Rowse’s high-end Manuka variety as well as the store’s own £16.50 version.They were both spotted in secure transparent plastic boxes by shopper Anton Rossi during a visit to the chain’s Putney High Street branch.Other products around them were not subject to the same measures.In a Facebook post he wrote: “In London, one needs to keep honey under lock and key...”Jack Higgins replied: “Easy pickings if it wasn’t for that blasted box.”And Chantel Cox added: “Manuka honey is fantastic for healing wounds and worth every penny.”Manuka honey is a favourite of Hollywood stars including Gwyneth Paltrow and Scarlett Johansson.Kourtney Kardashian swears that smearing it on her skin does wonders.It is made by bees from the nectar of the Manuka bush, which mainly grows in New Zealand and contains the active component methylglyoxal, or MGO.It is a particularly thick, deep-flavoured honey which is said to have amazing anti-bacterial, anti-viral and anti-microbial properties both in its natural form and when used in other medical products.It is claimed to have a number of health benefits, including treating acne and eczema, wounds and sore throats, combating MRSA, and improving immunity.Studies have shown that it speeds up the rate at which burns heal and it has also been touted as a cure for digestive issues.Experts from Southampton University found that manuka honey-based products could kill more than three quarters of potentially deadly bacteria that accumulates on surfaces — which could potentially save lives.There is currently no legal definition of what constitutes Manuka honey in the UK, which allows brands to sell products with little or no MGO content under the Manuka name.A Sainsburys spokesperson said: “Decisions on which products have security tags are made by individual stores.”It comes as Marks and Spencer announced it will close over 100 stores by 2022 as part of a radical restructuring plan.The retailer has now identified the latest 14 stores facing the axe, following on from the 21 that is has already closed.

title: royal portraits place in history
story: The formal photo of all the family and Meghan’s mum Doria Ragland not only ­features the Queen and the future king, but also the next and the one after that.The Queen and Prince Philip look a bit lost because there are so many bridesmaids and pageboys.But it is a great family ­picture and it’s clear Meghan’s mum Doria is now an important part of it.What is most amazing about the bridesmaids and pageboys is that all bar one are looking towards the camera. I know how difficult that can be.As a royal photographer, I particularly look at Prince George and Princess Charlotte. I can imagine their parents standing behind the camera trying to make them all laugh.It worked as George, who appeared to be a little grumpy at the service, is all smiles.The black and white picture is a bit arty for my taste. But the photographer Alexi Lubomirski, obviously prefers it because his best photo of their engagement was also in monochrome.Meghan, the beautiful actress, is in profile but you are drawn to Harry’s face. He is beaming with joy.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: diageo calls time on goldschlager in 1bn sell off
story: Private equity firms have commenced work on prospective bids for the portfolio, which Diageo is keen to sell in a single transaction, said one.The sale process is expected to last for several months.A City analyst said news of the auction indicated that Diageo was being disciplined about its global portfolio of more than 200 beer and spirits brands."The company has set out a focus on global, premium-and-above brands and price segments, and this appears to fit in with that," he said.Diageo declined to comment on the details of the sell-off.A spokesman for the company said: "We regularly review our portfolio to ensure we are maximising shareholder value."With a market capitalisation of close to &#16367bn, Diageo is one of the world's largest alcoholic drinks producers.Ivan Menezes, its chief executive since 2013, has intensified its attention on key global brands such as Johnnie Walker, the whisky, its 'ultra-premium' vodka Ciroc, Tanqueray gin and its Baileys cream liqueur.Mr Menezes had been under some pressure from investors during a period of faltering sales, but has been boosted by evidence that his strategy is paying off for Diageo.At its half-year results in January, the company said a 6.1% rise in operating profit to &#1632.2bn demonstrated "continued positive momentum".Diageo is perennially touted as a potential bid target for one of the few spirits groups larger than it by value or a financial investor such as 3G Capital, the owner of Kraft Heinz.Mr Menezes has sought to streamline the business by selling other assets including Gleneagles, the Scottish hotel and golf resort it offloaded for &#163200m three years ago.He then sanctioned the disposal of its wine portfolio a year later to Australia's Treasury Wine Estates in a &#163360m deal.

title: hawaiians watch lava eat their street in devastating slow motion
story: We pull in to Kaupili Street and an extraordinary scene.An active fissure is pushing a vast, bubbling lava field along the road, eating up trees and properties along the way.It gurgles and snakes forward, hissing and popping a slow motion, unstoppable destructive force. Incongruously, some residents have come to take selfies as the rainforest bursts into flames and the tarmac under our feet heats up.But for others this is an awful moment.Mum and daughter Lori and Alyssa Cruz comfort one another as the lava envelops a neatly painted postbox.They know if the lava keeps moving like this their home will be gone soon. Lori said: "I live right up here, and I have already evacuated everything."I just came down to say goodbye to my neighbourhood one last time."When you know everyone on this road, you're like a family, you know, it's devastating.Alyssa said: "I didn't know what to expect but I was hoping that my house wasn't going to get destroyed."I guess God had other plans."It is steam shooting up into the air from further back in the river of molten rock.The locals say it's time to move, worried it could be a new fissure opening up or the beginning of a series of explosions.From a slightly safer distance, we watch as it slows down, and people gather to wonder.Hawaii's Big Island is a spiritual place, and a surprising number of people directly affected by the eruptions have been resolutely philosophical about what is happening to them, often embracing the chance to commune with Pele, who they believe is the goddess of fire and volcanoes.Resident Howard Rosin said: "It is tragic and in another way it's really beautiful because it's absolute destruction and creation at the same time."It's primordial. Cosmic soup." Night falls and the sky glows orange above us.The wind shifts so we put gas masks on to protect against sulphur dioxide as we walk to a different vantage point.From the ridge we take in another extraordinary sight.Multiple fissures and merging lava fields stretch as far as we can see, the power of mount Kilauea on full display.

title: how russia bamboozles the world with its spin machine
story: And crucially it proved that it could work well enough to confuse and bamboozle the world's media with numerous, often contradictory false narratives. It has applied the same winning formula most effectively ever since.Russia responded to claims it had downed a passenger plane over Ukraine with tactics that are now very familiar. It blamed others.A Russian radar unit it said had seen a Ukrainian fighter jet in the area at the time.There was also a Ukrainian anti-aircraft missile unit in the vicinity.To back up these flimsy claims the Russians produced even flimsier evidence - satellite photos that were soon proved to have been doctored.A Spanish air traffic controller called 'Carlos' emerged on Twitter claiming that he witnessed Ukrainian fighter jets flying close to the doomed passenger plane. The Spanish government investigated and revealed 'Carlos' to be a fiction.The same playbook has been used since on claims of Russia's attempt to subvert US democracy, to the Skripal affair and Russia's complicity in the slaughter of civilians in Syria and its support for Syria's president Bashar al Assad despite his use of chemical weapons.It has also been used to devastating effect to undermine public trust in the institutions that underpin Western democracy, prosperity and security.And to weaken public faith in the news media we have relied on to maintain the integrity and proper functioning of those institutions.

title: jeremy corbyn not advocating irish unity referendum
story: Speaking on his first visit to Northern Ireland since becoming Labour leader, Mr Corbyn was asked if he would support reunification if he became prime minister at the next general election."It's a decision that could be made within the terms of the Good Friday Agreement," he told an audience at Queen's University Belfast."If that is the wish, such a poll would happen.

title: mh17 plane was brought down by russian military missile
story: Wilbert Paulissen, of the Dutch National Police, said the missile was from the Russian military's 53rd anti-aircraft missile brigade based in the city of Kursk.The team recreated the route taken by the missile convoy from Kursk across the border using videos and images."All the vehicles in a convoy carrying the missile were part of the Russian armed forces," Mr Paulissen told a televised news conference.He was speaking at a presentation of interim results of the long-running investigation into the downing of flight.Russia's defence ministry said it had nothing to do with the downing of the jet.Dutch investigators are focusing on some 100 people suspected of having played an "active role" in the incident, but they have not yet publicly named any of them.Chief investigator Fred Westerbeke said the probe was now in its "last phase" but added there was "still work to be done".

title: sky news witnesses spectacular explosions on north korea nuclear site
story: I observed and filmed what was said to be the entrance to the northern tunnel being demolished.This tunnel was the site of North Korea's five other nuclear tests to date, starting in 2009 and including its most recent in 2017 - thought be a hydrogen bomb.A log cabin observatory nearby was also demolished in spectacular fashion.North Korean officials showed journalists the tunnels before they were blown.The entrances were ostentatiously rigged with wires and bags of what we were told were plastic explosives.The two unused tunnels, the western and southern, had remained usable, officials insisted.Media reports suggested they may have previously collapsed.The deputy director of North Korea's Nuclear Weapons Institute, who would not give his name and held the rank of general, told me these tunnels hadn't "suffered the slightest damage" and were "intact at this moment".The site was still "fully prepared to conduct nuclear tests", he added.Another officer from the institute, a colonel, said the western tunnel had been prepared for an even bigger detonation than the one carried out in September 2017, before a halt was called to nuclear testing by North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un.The entrances to both western and southern tunnels were subsequently demolished too.Only journalists were allowed to observe the demolition taking place no weapons inspectors or nuclear experts were invited. We were also prevented from taking GPS devices to the site, as well as equipment to measure radiation.We did not observe any radiation monitors at the site.The layout of the site did appear to match satellite images previously taken of Punggye-ri.At a ceremony proclaiming the closure of the site later, the unnamed deputy director of the Nuclear Weapons Institute said: "The dismantling of the nuclear test ground conducted with high levels of transparency has clearly attested once again to the proactive and peace-loving efforts of the government of the DPRK being made for the peace and stability of the Korean peninsula and the world.

title: what we know about north koreas secretive punggye ri nuclear site
story: In April, North Korean leader Kim Jong Un announced his country would suspend nuclear and missile tests, as well as closing Punggye-ri.But some scientists have said that the site may have been rendered useless months ago anyway.It is thought that the site partially collapsed after the September test.In October, a Japanese news outlet reported that a tunnel being built at the site had collapsed and as many as 200 workers were dead.And in December, two aftershocks were detected, raising concerns about the stability of the mountain.

title: home office immigration chief hugh
story: NewsHome Office immigration chief Hugh Ind dramatically leaves his role after outrage over Windrush scandalHugh Ind, who was director-general of immigration enforcement, is being moved out of the Home Office within weeks after a 27-year career&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDan BloomPolitical reporter12:30, 24 MAY 2018Updated12:43, 24 MAY 2018NewsHugh Ind is moving out of the Home Office after 27 years in the department (Image: Parliament Live TV)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The head of immigration enforcement at the Home Office has dramatically left his role after outrage over the handling of the Windrush scandal .  Hugh Ind, who was director-general of immigration enforcement, is being moved out of the Home Office after 27 years' service in the department. He will take up a new role in the Cabinet Office within the next three weeks. The move is so quick he will be replaced by an interim director-general, current asylum chief Tyson Hepple, while a permanent replacement is found. A Home Office spokeswoman declined to say whether Mr Ind's departure was due to the Windrush scandal. Officials claimed he had neither resigned nor been sacked - simply moved.  Mr Ind was the official who prepared a leaked memo showing the Home Office had a target of achieving 12,800 enforced returns in 2017-18. The leak last month triggered a chain of events that led to Home Secretary Amber Rudd resigning after she denied targets existed. Mr Ind also returned to the spotlight when he confirmed there had been “a handful” of wrongful deportations overall in the last six years. The staffing changes were announced by Home Office permanent secretary Sir Philip Rutnam in a low-key notice buried on the government website. He thanked Mr Ind for his huge contribution to the Home Office and unswerving dedication to public service, and wished him every possible success going forward. Mr Ind, who joined the Home Office in 1991, will now lead the Public Sector Apprenticeships Strategy. The 'Windrush generation' are British residents who arrived from Commonwealth countries before New Year's Day 1973. They are named after the Empire Windrush, the ship which brought some of the first Caribbean migrants to Britain in 1948. Anyone who arrived in the UK from a Commonwealth country before 1973 has a legal right to stay, unless they left the UK for more than two years. But they faced being threatened with deportation under new immigration rules despite living and working here for decades. People were ordered to prove they have the right to be in the UK to rent property, work or access services and benefits. The government failed to keep detailed records of Windrush arrivals, and landing cards were destroyed in 2010. The Home Office set up a task force with the aim of sorting out cases within two weeks. Windrush immigrants are also being granted fee-free citizenship and a compensation scheme, the rules of which have not been set yet. Read more if you're affected here or call a government hotline on 0300 123 2241 (option 1).

title: russian pranksters hold 18 minute
story: NewsBoris Johnson pranked in excruciating 18-minute phone call by Russian blaggerThe shock audio of a caller pretending to Armenia's Prime Minister was released by pranksters Lexus and Vovan in what appears to be a major breach of UK national security&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDan BloomPolitical reporter14:02, 24 MAY 2018Updated15:52, 24 MAY 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailRussian pranksters linked to the Kremlin held an excruciating 18-minute phone call with Boris Johnson by pretending to be the Prime Minister of Armenia. The shock audio was released on YouTube today in what appears to be an extraordinary breach of UK national security. Mr Johnson was scrupulously diplomatic through most of the call, which he used to condemn Russia's behaviour, vow a crackdown on oligarchs and talk about the poisoning of Sergei Skripal. But the UK Foreign Secretary then persistently asked for more detail when told about fake claims that the Kremlin had given money to Jeremy Corbyn. And he confirmed that ex-spy Skripal and his daughter Yulia are both still in the UK, though he didn't specify where. The video was tweeted today by Russian pranksters Alexei Stolyarov and Vladimir Kuznetsov, who style themselves Lexus and Vovan. A Foreign Office spokesman confirmed it was real, saying: The Foreign Secretary realised it was a hoax, and ended the call. We checked it out and knew immediately it was a prank call. The use of chemical weapons in Salisbury and Syria, and recent events in Armenia are serious matters. These childish actions show the lack of seriousness of the caller and those behind him. Critics claim the pair have links to the Russian security services and a senior UK diplomatic source said: This seems to be the latest desperate attempt by the Kremlin to save face after it was internationally shamed in the wake of the Skripal attack.  Boris rumbled them pretty quickly and ended the call. It is tragic to see a major international power reduced to failed pranks you would usually only see on Trigger Happy TV. Armenia, located in the sensitive eastern bloc near Georgia and the Russian border, elected its new Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan earlier this month. Mr Johnson started the call by congratulating him and calling for the UK and Armenia to strengthen relations forthwith. In return, the man posing as Pashinyan thanked Mr Johnson for giving the time on his day off. He also said I'm a fan of your poetry - picking out a satirical poem Mr Johnson wrote about the Turkish President having sex with a goat. Early in the call, Mr Johnson said Russia was unable to resist malign activity and we have to stand firm against them. You throw a stone in Kensington and you’ll hit an oligarch, the Foreign Secretary said. It's very important for the Russians to know that certainly the UK is absolutely determined to stand against them.  We will continue to tighten the squeeze on some of the oligarchs who surround Putin. But the call got increasingly awkward towards the end as the man posing as Pashinyan said Russian President Vladimir Putin has influence over Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn. Oh really, well, that - did he tell you that? Boris Johnson replied. Yes, he told me, the man replied. Boris Johnson replied: Really. He told you that he was influencing Jeremy Corbyn? The response came: Yes, absolutely.

title: theresa refuses again set date
story: NewsTheresa May refuses AGAIN to set a date for crucial Brexit votes amid fears Tory rebels will winMPs were told they won't be able to debate 15 defeats to the EU Withdrawal Bill, which were inflicted in the House of Lords, until at least June 11&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDan BloomPolitical reporter11:57, 24 MAY 2018News (Image: PA)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe government kicked crucial Brexit votes down the road AGAIN today amid fears pro-Remain Tory rebels could storm to victory.  MPs were told they won't be able to debate 15 defeats to the EU Withdrawal Bill , which were inflicted in the House of Lords, until at least June 11.  The apparent last-minute delay came despite Tory Chief Whip Julian Smith telling MPs they could expect a showdown in the near future. One furious Tory pointed the blame on the whips' office, saying the behaviour was unhelpful and discourteous. It means the Bill - which converts EU law into UK law - will have been out of the House of Lords for almost a month before it is even debated again, let alone voted on.  It comes amid reports that deadlocked Theresa May is trying to delay the end of a transition period until 2023 - which Downing Street denied.    The Lords amendments could force Theresa May back to the negotiating table, remove the fixed March 29 Brexit date, and keep Britain in the EU customs union permanently.   The government wants to overturn as many of the 15 defeats as possible, but will face opposition from Labour, the Lib Dems, SNP and Tory rebels.  Theresa May has a tiny Commons majority so a handful of rebels would be enough to inflict defeat - and change the course of Brexit. For the same reason, the timing of the crucial Customs Bill and Trade Bill have still not been announced yet either.

title: tory government quietly drops key
story: NewsTory government quietly drops key pledge to 'fix the broken housing market' from official plansEXCLUSIVE: The slogan has been scrubbed from the Housing Ministry's formal plan, months after Theresa May made it key to the Conservative Conference&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDan BloomPolitical reporter15:42, 24 MAY 2018Updated15:43, 24 MAY 2018NewsThe Prime Minister pledged to fix the broken housing market (Image: REUTERS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Tory government has quietly dropped its key pledge to 'fix the broken housing market' from official plans. The slogan was scrubbed from top Housing Ministry documents just months after Theresa May made it a central vow at the Conservative Party Conference. Used by Tory ministers since at least 2016, 'Fixing our broken housing market' was the title of a government White Paper in February last year. The 2017 Tory manifesto also vowed to fix the dysfunctional housing market before the Prime Minister used the phrase in her October conference speech. It was last used by Tory ministers just three days ago. But the slogan has vanished from the Housing Ministry's annual 'single departmental plan' - where it was previously objective number one. It has been replaced by deliver the homes the country needs in the new plan, which was published with little fanfare on Wednesday.  Neither the words fix nor broken feature in the new plan. Government sources today insisted no policy had changed - just the wording of the slogan. But Shadow Housing Secretary John Healey said: Words count and what the government says matters. Even Tory Ministers now admit they have no plan to fix the housing crisis. It's been eight years of failure all fronts on housing from falling home-ownership to rapidly rising homelessness. The new plan promises to make the vision of a place you call home a reality and create socially and economically stronger and more confident communities.

title: feminist meghan markle going more
story: NewsopinionFeminist Meghan Markle is going to be more than just Prince Harry's arm candyThe Duchess of Sussex will be using her huge platform to support causes that help the advancement of women - and insiders say she has the blessing of the palace to do so&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByEva Simpson00:13, 23 MAY 2018NewsopinionMeghan is a breath of fresh air who will shake up the Royal Family (Image: Getty)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe confetti has been swept away, Serena Williams has stopped giving us updates on Instagram and the embarrassing Markle half-siblings have headed back to America, hopefully never to be heard from again. And now, for the Duchess of Sussex, the serious work begins.  She and Prince Harry were already back on royal duties yesterday at a Buckingham Palace garden party celebrating Prince Charles’ 70th birthday .  But she has made it clear that her role in “the Firm” will be to do more than wear stylish dresses or just be arm candy for her husband.  Shortly after the wedding, her official biography on the Buckingham Palace website was out and in it she boldly announced she is “proud to be a woman and a feminist”. It was a signal she will be using her huge platform to support causes that help the advancement of women. Insiders say she has the blessing of the palace to do so.  It didn’t take long for the haters to pile in at the mention of the word feminist and I must admit that I initially groaned at the thought.  Of course I believe in equality of men and women which, by definition, makes me a feminist. But I’ve always felt excluded from feminism and feminist debates because they’re always dominated by one voice – well-off middle-class women. Instead of being inclusive, it is exclusive and rarely addresses the views and needs of ethnic minority or working-class women. It seems those who benefit most are usually already well paid and well connected. I’ve been to networking events about gender equality in business or the media and I can usually count the number of non-white women on one hand. During panel discussions I never hear anyone talking about tackling the lack of social or racial diversity. Instead it’s a certain group of women fighting for women like themselves. Women of colour have fought against sexism and racism, but their voice is rarely heard. I believe Meghan can change that. Yes she’s well-off and privileged, but her background, and the fact she was raised by a black woman, gives her a different perspective.  As her bio says, she’s had a keen awareness of social issues from an early age, instilled by her wonderful mother Doria Ragland . “Those early experiences helped shape her lifelong commitment to causes such as social justice and women’s empowerment,” it says.

title: landlord who drank 50 pints
story: NewsLandlord who drank 50 PINTS a week loses nine stone after ditching Stella ArtoisAdam Joy, 40, would down endless pints gifted to him by punters and then get a kebab - but the turning point came when he couldn't walk up the steps at Twickenham&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByOlive Loveridge-Green13:18, 24 MAY 2018Updated13:42, 24 MAY 2018NewsHe was a man who loved a takeaway (Image: SWNS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA landlord lost nine stone in six months after he ditched his unhealthy diet of fast food and 50 pints of Stella Artois lager - a WEEK. Ex-boozer Adam Joy, 40, consumed a staggering 12,800 calories in lager alone every week - which is three-quarters of the total recommended intake for a man. Thanks to the endless pints gifted to him by punters, he was consuming a dangerous 135 units of alcohol a week when the safe total is just 14. But he decided to overhaul his unhealthy lifestyle when he reached 26st 4lbs and struggled to make it up the stairs at a Twickenham game with his son.  As well as ditching the booze, he swapped fatty kebabs for home-cooked dishes and even introduced healthy curry nights at his boozer, the Bird in Hand in Dartford, Kent. In just six months he has lost nine stone - and is still losing more every week - and has been named Male Slimmer of the Year at his Slimming World group. He now cooks all the family meals for wife Carol-Ann, 46, and kids Caitlin, 19, and Jack, 13, rustling up the likes of veg, meat and fruit.  Adam has also taken to cutting off all the fat from the meat and no longer suffers from arthritis and high blood pressure.   He also often posts on Slimming World's Pinch of Nom Facebook group with complete strangers asking him for help.   Adam now hopes his incredible weight loss story will help inspire men up and down the country to shift the pounds. He said: I started becoming unhappy after seeing pics of myself at my 40th birthday party last August. Then when I took my son to the England game at a Twickenham game I realised how unfit I was. We had seats at the top of the stadium and I was struggling to make my way up. But I've completely turned it around now. If I can do it anybody can. I've managed to shift the weight because when I do something I always commit. Beforehand I was boozing heavily and eating really unhealthy. If walked past a bakery I just had to go in.  Also working behind the bar meant that every night was a Friday night. We'd have darts on Monday and Wednesdays and quiz nights on Thursdays. Punters would always offer to buy me a drink and I'd always accept. I wouldn't have lunch or dinner during a stint behind the bar. I would wait until the shift ended before ordering myself a takeaway - it was usually a kebab. Since joining Slimming World I've felt great. Before joining I was 26st 4lbs. I'm down to 17st 4lbs which I haven't been since I was 18-years-old. Adam has won Slimmer of the Week award 12 times as well as nabbing the Slimmer of the Month gong for the last four months. He has also won Male Slimmer of the Year after shifting more weight than any other bloke.  His healthy eating habits have even rubbed off on his regulars with around 25 taking to his low-fat homemade curries in his award winning boozer. He continued: At the weekend I had my 40th birthday suit refitted. I lost six inches on my neck, 14 inches on my chest and 12 inches on my waist. The tailors were astonished by my weight loss. I hope my story inspires blokes to take up weight loss and Slimming World. I'm a real man's man and when I walked into the class I was greeted to a room full of women.

story: NewsMeghan Markle's cheeky page boy reveals what made him pull THAT face as the stunning bride walked into churchBrian Mulroney and his twin brother John had the important job of carrying Meghan's veil - and they looked very excited&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByZoe ForseySocial Audience Writer11:11, 24 MAY 2018Updated12:08, 24 MAY 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAfter Meghan's stunning dress and that romantic first kiss, one of the big talking points from Prince Harry's wedding was the adorable little page boy who stole the show with his excited facial expressions. story: NewsMeghan Markle to get 'six month crash course' on how to be a royal from Queen's special adviserThe new Duchess of Sussex will be taught the ropes by Buckingham Palace adviser Samantha Cohen, who was at the royal wedding&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter09:05, 24 MAY 2018Updated10:24, 24 MAY 2018NewsMeghan Markle is set for a six month 'crash course' listening to royal expert Samantha Cohen (Image: PA)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMeghan Markle will have a crash course in 'how to be a royal' with advice from the Queen's special adviser, according to reports. The new Duchess of Sussex will be assisted by Samantha Cohen, 49, who had been the Queen's assistant private secretary, and is expected to be brought up to speed with protocol and expectations of life with the monarchy. Ms Cohen gave notice of her resignation last September following the ousting of Sir Christopher, 56, the Queen's private secretary, who announced in July he was leaving after 15 years of royal service. But she has now agreed to stay on as interim private secretary to Prince Harry and Meghan Markle, according to The Times. The Duchess of Sussex, 36, is planning to spend six month's learning how to be an effective member of the royal family, the paper adds.   Samantha, an Australian and reportedly one of the Queen's most trusted aides, will guide the newlyweds through their first year of marriage.  It is thought Meghan will spend the rest of the year meeting charities and other good causes in a national tour only punctuated by their honeymoon while learning from mentor Ms Cohen, a mum of three.  A source told The Times: It will be six months of listening.  She is seeking out advice from a range of people. She is going to proceed with humility.   It is not going to be quiet, though. It is going to be a very busy office. She has worked every day of her life. She is used to a demanding schedule. Meghan - who announced her retirement from acting following her engagement to Prince Harry - has already made her first official outing in her new role at a garden party at Buckingam Palace to celebrate her father-in-law, Prince Charles, turning 70 this year. The garden party saw 6,000 guests enjoy the sunshine and a speech from the Duke of Sussex celebrating the charity work of his father - despite being momentarily distracted by a bee - much to his new wife's amusement. It is claimed Samantha Cohen found herself at the centre of an incredibly power struggle between Buckingham Palace and the Prince of Wales last year.  The Queen's most senior courtier Sir Christopher Geidt announced he was leaving in July last year following 15 years of service to the royal family. Two months later Ms Cohen, the third most senior courtier, submitted her resignation. Sources at the time claimed that the 49-year-old had quit in solidarity with Sir Christopher, who had been ousted following a series of complaints from Prince Charles and Prince Andrew with the Queen backing her sons over her staff.

story: NewsRoyal Wedding facts: From the cake, to the cost and big moments you may have missedNow we've had time to process everything that happened on the big day, we look at the facts and figures from Prince Harry and Meghan Markle's big day&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByJo-Anne RowneyDeputy Audience Growth Editor17:26, 23 MAY 2018Updated12:46, 24 MAY 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email It was to be expected, but Prince Harry and Meghan Markle's wedding day was a huge undertaking - taking a massive amount of time, money and teamwork to make it all come together.  The couple tied the knot at St George's Chapel on May 19 in an extravagant - but touching - ceremony. Their family and friends gathered - along with millions of people around the world - to see the happy pair say I do. With so much going on though you may have missed a few things. It's a little frightening when you consider how much work went into a single day. We've taken a look at the facts and figures to break it all down for you. Meghan followed in Princess Diana's footsteps Harry and Meghan read traditional vows from the Common Book of Prayer, though Meghan left out the word obey - just like Diana did. Kate Middleton also left the word out when she married William in 2011. Meghan made history  Meghan began her wedding procession alone - after her father remained in the USA or an operation - though she was joined by Prince Charles at the Quire. She's the first royal bride to walk down the aisle without an escort. Meghan and Harry got new titles Hours before the wedding, the Queen announced they were now the Duke and Duchess of Sussex. Their wedding rings broke with tradition Harry broke with tradition, choosing to wear a wedding band. He went with a platinum band with a textured finish. Meghan's was made of Welsh gold, which Queen Elizabeth gifted to her.  There were a ton of celebs at the wedding and reception  David and Victoria Beckham were there, as were Amal and George Clooney. James Corden rocked up with his wife, and compered the reception later, even getting the royals to dance off. Meghan's friends, including Serena Williams, Priyanka Chopra and her Suits co-stars also were invited to the wedding.  Harry's exes were at the wedding Cressida Bonas and Chelsy Davis both attended, but everyone was fine with it, because that's what the royals do. Meghan's veil had intricate details  The 15-ft long veil was designed by Givenchy's Clare Waight Keller. She had flowers for every single commonwealth country as per Meghan's request. Meghan wedding dress  The first was by Givenchy, the second was by Stella McCartney and was more Hollywood in its look - a lily white halter neck. Meghan wore shoes from Aquazurra made in silky satin, with nude mesh and soles painted in baby blue.  Meghan's tiara was her something old She wore Queen Mary's old tiara which was lent to her by Queen Elizabeth II. She deliberately had subtle make up Just like Kate, Meghan had her close friends do her makeup rather than a professional.  Meghan's dad wasn't there Thomas Markle Snr had causes quite the drama beforehand. He was set to attend the wedding, but caused controversy when it was revealed pap pictures of him reading a book about London and googling his daughter were set up. It later emerged he needed a heart operation and would be unable to fly to the wedding or walk Meghan down the aisle. He told TMZ: My baby looks beautiful, and she looks very happy. He added: I wish I were there, and I wish them all my love and happiness.  Though her mum was - and alone   Doria Ragland sat alone, though it's thought the Bride and Groom sorted the seating. Harry's family were on the right, Meghan's on the left. She had a tear in her eye as she watched her daughter get married. What Harry said to Charles When Prince Charles reached Harry at the altar , Harry looked at him and said: Thank you, Pa. The entertainment in the church was amazing There were 23 boy choristers from St George's School as well as Sheku Kanneh-Mason, the 19-year-old who won BBC Young Musician of the Year, who was the cellist at the wedding. There was also a gospel choir who sang Etta James and Stand By Me. There were twins as page boys  The son of Meghan's best friend Jessica were page boys - Brian and John held her veil and looked very excited about it all. Prince George was also a page boy and his sister Charlotte was a bridesmaid.  Jasper Dyer, 6, was also a pageboy.  Who were Meghan's bridemaids? There were no adult bridemaids. Meghan chose children to take on the roles. Florence van Cutsem, 3, Zalie Warren, 2 - and Markle's goddaughters - Remi and Rylan Litt.  Jessica Mulroney daughter Ivy, 4, was also a bridemaid.   There was an A-list guestlist 600 invitations were made by Barnard &amp Westwood for the event, though only 200 were invited to Frogmore House. The couple also invited members of the public, with 2,640 people getting an invite. Made up of 1,200 nominated by nine regional Lord Lieutenent officers 200 people from charities and organisations 100 pupils from local schools the Royal School and St George's School 610 Windsor Castle's community members 530 members of the Royal Households and Crown Estate. Bishop Michael Curry went down a storm  The preacher gave a stirring sermon, that had the royals looking a little shocked. People seemed to love it though, and the message about civil rights, love and the power to change the world. It was a big logistical event Volunteers helped out on the day, with 140 Royal Borough Ambassadors stewarding. It cost &pound30 to park at the Review Ground on the day, and there were 6,000 spots. Security operation About &pound30m was spent on security for the wedding. The Met Police identified 160 'stalkers' before the event.  TV channels All the channels from around the world descended on Windsor. Most impressive though was Sky who laid 27km of cable to broadcast the coverage in UHD, making them the first broadcaster to televise it in 4k. Their first dance was to Whitney Houston They went for something a bit different and had I Wanna Dance With Somebody - instead of dancing alone they invited their guests to the dancefloor with them. They went into a bit of jive and lindy hop. Jaguar E-Type  The number plate was the date of the wedding. The car was a silver blue classic convertible Jaguar E-Type Concept Zero, originally made in 1968 but made into an electric car. The reception was at Frogmore House ...so called because of the frogs that live in the low lying marshy area. It's only open on three ticketed charity days. Guests partied in a glass marquee, it was also where they had their sit down meal.  The cake was massive There was quite an ingredients list for the cake.   The flowers were donated to a hospice  Floral designer Phillippa Craddock directed a team, including florists from St George's Chapel and Buckingham Palace, to create the wedding displays. They had a great evening reception  There's so many details from the reception we gathered them all together in our behind-the-scenes break down of what happened .
